a.definition: Used when referring to someone or something for the first time
examples: A cat sat on the mat

ability.definition: Possession of the means or skill to do something
examples: She has the ability to learn quickly
His ability in mathematics is remarkable
ability.etymology: Middle English: from Old French abilite, from Latin habilitas

about.etymology: Old English abutan, from on + butan 'outside'

above.definition: In extended space over and not touching
examples: The plane flew above the clouds
above.etymology: Old English abufan, from a- 'on' + bufan 'above'

abstract.definition: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence
examples: Abstract concepts like love and justice
abstract.etymology: Latin abstractus, past participle of abstrahere 'draw away'

accept.definition: Consent to receive or undertake something offered
accept.etymology: Latin acceptare, frequentative of accipere 'take to oneself'

access.definition: The means or opportunity to approach or enter a place
examples: Access to the building is restricted
access.etymology: Middle English: from Old French acces or Latin accessus

account.definition: A report or description of an event or experience
examples: Give me an account of what happened
account.etymology: Middle English: from Old French acont, from aconter

examples: The report was accurate and detailed
accurate.etymology: Latin accuratus, past participle of accurare 'do with care'

achieve.definition: Successfully bring about or reach a desired objective
achieve.etymology: Middle English: from Old French achever 'come to a head'

action.definition: The fact or process of doing something
examples: The action of the movie was exciting
action.etymology: Middle English: via Old French from Latin actio(n-)

active.definition: Engaging or ready to engage in physically energetic pursuits
active.etymology: Middle English: from Latin activus, from act- 'done'

actual.etymology: Middle English: from Old French actuel, from late Latin actualis

add.definition: Join something to something else so as to increase the size
add.etymology: Middle English: from Latin addere, from ad- 'to' + dare 'put'

address.definition: The particulars of the place where someone lives or works
address.etymology: Middle English: from Old French adresser, based on Latin ad- 'towards' + directus 'direct'

administration.definition: The process or activity of running a business or organization
administration.etymology: Middle English: via Old French from Latin administratio(n-)

adult.definition: A person who is fully grown or developed
adult.etymology: Latin adultus, past participle of adolescere 'grow up'

advance.definition: Move forward in a purposeful way
advance.etymology: Middle English: from Old French avancer, from late Latin abante 'in front'

advantage.definition: A condition or circumstance that puts one in a favorable position
examples: Being tall is an advantage in basketball
advantage.etymology: Middle English: from Old French avantage, from avant 'in front'

adventure.definition: An unusual and exciting or daring experience
examples: Their trip was quite an adventure
adventure.etymology: Middle English: from Old French aventure, from Latin adventurus 'about to happen'

advice.definition: Guidance or recommendations offered with regard to prudent action
examples: Can you give me some advice?
advice.etymology: Middle English: from Old French avis, based on Latin ad- 'to' + visum, past participle of videre 'to see'

affect.definition: Have an effect on; make a difference to
examples: The rain will affect our plans
How did the medicine affect you?
affect.etymology: Late Middle English: from French affecter or Latin afficere 'work on, influence'

after.definition: In the time following an event or another period of time
after.etymology: Old English æfter, of Germanic origin

age.definition: The length of time that a person has lived or a thing has existed
age.etymology: Middle English: from Old French, based on Latin aetas

agency.definition: A business or organization providing a particular service
agency.etymology: Mid 17th century: from medieval Latin agentia, from Latin agere 'do'

agent.definition: A person who acts on behalf of another person or group
agent.etymology: Late Middle English: from Latin agent- 'doing', from the verb agere

ago.etymology: Middle English: past participle of obsolete ago 'pass by'

agree.definition: Have the same opinion about something
examples: We agreed to meet at noon
agree.etymology: Middle English: from Old French agreer, based on Latin ad- 'to' + gratus 'pleasing'

agreement.definition: A negotiated and typically legally binding arrangement
agreement.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French agreement

ahead.definition: Further forward in space; in the line of one's forward motion
ahead.etymology: Middle English: from a- 'on, in' + head

aid.definition: Help, typically of a practical nature
aid.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French aide, aidier, based on Latin adjuvare

aim.definition: Point or direct a weapon or camera at a target
examples: Aim the camera at the subject
What do you aim to achieve?
aim.etymology: Middle English: from Old French esmer, from Latin aestimare

air.definition: The invisible gaseous substance surrounding the earth
air.etymology: Middle English: via Old French from Latin aer, from Greek aēr

aircraft.definition: An airplane, helicopter, or other machine capable of flight

all.definition: Used to refer to the whole quantity or extent of something
all.etymology: Old English eall, of Germanic origin

allow.definition: Give permission for something to happen
allow.etymology: Middle English: from Old French alouer, from Latin allaudare 'approve'

almost.etymology: Old English eallmǣst, from eall 'all' + mǣst 'most'

alone.definition: Having no one else present; on one's own

along.definition: In company with or at the same time as
along.etymology: Old English andlang, from and- 'against' + lang 'long'

already.definition: Before or by now or the time in question

also.etymology: Old English eallswā, from eall 'all' + swā 'so'

although.definition: In spite of the fact that; even though

always.definition: At all times; on all occasions

amazing.definition: Causing great surprise or wonder; astonishing

among.definition: Situated more or less centrally in relation to several other things
among.etymology: Old English onmang, from on 'in' + mang 'assemblage'

amount.definition: A quantity of something, especially the total of a thing
amount.etymology: Middle English: from Old French amonter, from amont 'upward'

analysis.definition: Detailed examination of the elements or structure of something
analysis.etymology: Late 16th century: via medieval Latin from Greek analusis

analyze.etymology: Early 17th century: from French analyser, from analyse

ancient.definition: Belonging to the very distant past
ancient.etymology: Middle English: from Old French ancien, based on Latin ante 'before'

and.definition: Used to connect words of the same part of speech
and.etymology: Old English and, ond, of Germanic origin

anger.definition: A strong feeling of annoyance, displeasure, or hostility
anger.etymology: Middle English: from Old Norse angr 'grief'

animal.definition: A living organism that feeds on organic matter
animal.etymology: Middle English: from Latin animal, based on animalis 'having breath'

another.definition: Used to refer to an additional person or thing of the same type

answer.definition: A thing said, written, or done to deal with a question
answer.etymology: Old English andswaru, of Germanic origin

any.definition: Used to refer to one or some of a thing, no matter how much or many

anything.definition: Used to refer to a thing, no matter what

appear.definition: Come into sight; become visible or noticeable
appear.etymology: Middle English: from Old French aparoir, from Latin apparere

application.definition: A formal request to an authority for something
application.etymology: Late Middle English: from Latin applicatio(n-)

apply.definition: Make a formal application or request
apply.etymology: Middle English: from Old French aplier, from Latin applicare 'fold, fasten to'

approach.definition: Come near or nearer to someone or something in distance
approach.etymology: Middle English: from Old French aprochier, from ecclesiastical Latin appropiare

appropriate.definition: Suitable or proper in the circumstances
appropriate.etymology: Late Middle English: from late Latin appropriatus

area.definition: A region or part of a town, country, or the world
area.etymology: Mid 16th century: from Latin, literally 'vacant piece of level ground'

argue.definition: Give reasons or cite evidence in support of an idea
argue.etymology: Middle English: from Old French arguer, from Latin arguere 'make clear, prove'

argument.definition: An exchange of diverging or opposite views
argument.etymology: Middle English: via Old French from Latin argumentum

arm.definition: Each of the two upper limbs of the human body
arm.etymology: Old English earm, of Germanic origin

army.definition: An organized military force equipped for fighting on land
army.etymology: Middle English: from Old French armee, from Latin armata

around.definition: Located or situated on every side

arrive.definition: Reach a place at the end of a journey or a stage in a journey
arrive.etymology: Middle English: from Old French ariver, based on Latin ad- 'to' + ripa 'shore'

art.definition: The expression or application of human creative skill
art.etymology: Middle English: via Old French from Latin ars, art-

article.etymology: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin articulus 'small connecting part'

artist.definition: A person who produces paintings or drawings as a profession
artist.etymology: Early 16th century: from French artiste, from Italian artista

as.definition: Used in comparisons to refer to the extent or degree
as.etymology: Old English eallswā, from eall 'all' + swā 'so'

ask.definition: Say something in order to obtain an answer or information
ask.etymology: Old English āscian, of West Germanic origin

assume.definition: Suppose to be the case, without proof
assume.etymology: Late Middle English: from Latin assumere, from ad- 'to' + sumere 'take'

at.definition: Expressing location or arrival in a particular place
at.etymology: Old English æt, of Germanic origin

attack.definition: Take aggressive action against a place or enemy forces
attack.etymology: Early 17th century: from French attaque, attaquer, from Italian attaccare 'join battle'

attempt.definition: Make an effort to achieve or complete something
attempt.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French atempter, from Latin attemptare

attend.definition: Be present at an event, meeting, or function
attend.etymology: Middle English: from Old French atendre, from Latin attendere

attention.definition: Notice taken of someone or something
attention.etymology: Late Middle English: from Latin attentio(n-)

attitude.definition: A settled way of thinking or feeling about someone or something
attitude.etymology: Late 17th century: from French, from Italian attitudine 'fitness'

attract.definition: Cause to come to a place or participate in a venture
attract.etymology: Late Middle English: from Latin attract- 'drawn to'

available.definition: Able to be used or obtained; at someone's disposal

avoid.definition: Keep away from or stop oneself from doing something
avoid.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French evuider 'clear out, get rid of'

away.definition: To or at a distance from a particular place
away.etymology: Old English onweg, from on 'on' + weg 'way'

baby.definition: A very young child, especially one newly or recently born
baby.etymology: Late Middle English: probably imitative of an infant's first attempts at speech

back.definition: The rear surface of the human body
back.etymology: Old English bæc, of Germanic origin

bad.definition: Of poor quality or a low standard
bad.etymology: Middle English: perhaps from Old English bæddel 'hermaphrodite'

bag.definition: A flexible container with an opening at the top
bag.etymology: Middle English: from Old Norse baggi

ball.definition: A solid or hollow sphere, especially one that is kicked or thrown
ball.etymology: Middle English: from Old Norse böllr

bank.definition: A financial establishment that uses money deposited by customers
bank.etymology: Late Middle English: from French banque or Italian banca

bar.definition: A long rigid piece of wood, metal, or similar material
bar.etymology: Middle English: from Old French barre

base.definition: The lowest part or edge of something
base.etymology: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin basis

basic.definition: Forming an essential foundation or starting point

battle.definition: A sustained fight between large organized armed forces
battle.etymology: Middle English: from Old French bataille

examples: To be or not to be
be.etymology: Old English bēon, of Germanic origin

beat.definition: Strike repeatedly so as to inflict pain
beat.etymology: Old English bēatan, of Germanic origin

beautiful.definition: Pleasing the senses or mind aesthetically

examples: I'm tired because I worked late

become.definition: Begin to be; grow to be
become.etymology: Old English becuman, from be- + cuman 'come'

bed.definition: A piece of furniture for sleep or rest
bed.etymology: Old English bedd, of Germanic origin

before.definition: During the period of time preceding a particular event
before.etymology: Old English beforan, from be- 'by' + foran 'in front'

begin.definition: Start; perform or undergo the first part of an action
begin.etymology: Old English beginnan, of Germanic origin

behavior.definition: The way in which one acts or conducts oneself

behind.definition: At the back of; at or to the far side of
behind.etymology: Old English behindan, from be- 'by' + hindan 'from behind'

believe.definition: Accept that something is true, especially without proof
believe.etymology: Old English belēfan, belīefan, from be- + līefan

benefit.definition: An advantage or profit gained from something
benefit.etymology: Late Middle English: from Old French bienfet

best.definition: Of the most excellent or desirable type or quality
best.etymology: Old English betst, of Germanic origin

better.etymology: Old English betera, of Germanic origin

between.definition: At, into, or across the space separating two objects
between.etymology: Old English betwēonan, from be- 'by' + twēonan 'two each'

beyond.definition: At or to the further side of
beyond.etymology: Old English begeondan, from be- 'by' + geondan 'yonder'

big.definition: Of considerable size, extent, or intensity

bill.definition: A statement of charges for goods or services
bill.etymology: Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French bille

billion.definition: The number equivalent to the product of a thousand and a million
billion.etymology: Late 17th century: from French, from bi- 'two' + million

bit.definition: A small piece, part, or quantity of something
bit.etymology: Old English bita, from bītan 'to bite'

black.definition: Of the very darkest color owing to the absence of light
black.etymology: Old English blæc, of Germanic origin

blood.definition: The red liquid that circulates in arteries and veins
blood.etymology: Old English blōd, of Germanic origin

blue.definition: Of a color intermediate between green and violet
blue.etymology: Middle English: from Old French bleu, of Germanic origin

board.definition: A long thin flat piece of wood or other hard material
board.etymology: Old English bord, of Germanic origin

boat.definition: A small vessel propelled on water by oars, sails, or engine
